children.value: You'd think I'd be tired of
, but it hasn't gotten old for me yet. Recently, I had the opportunity at
to built some flashy geographically oriented animations for a video we were putting together and the first thing that came to mind was to use the excellent
I wanted to have a glitzy reveal of all 17,000+ public libraries in the US and ended up with the following:
This post will cover how to make something like that yourself.
Basic point animation using transitions with ScatterplotLayer
If you haven't used deck.gl before, check out
for details on how to get started.
The first approach we'll try for bringing animation to our map vis is to leverage the built-in support for
This will render our libraries as a bunch of points colored

padding-bottom: 56.29397967161845%; position: relative; bottom: 0; left: 0; background-image: url('data:image/png;base64,'); background-size: cover; display: block;

children.value: Now if we want to animate the colors of the points, we can modify our layer props to include
We're using the transitions shorthand here, which says when the
value changes we should transition to the new value over 3000ms.
If you're using a function to specify
, you may also need to provide a value for
so deck.gl knows it needs to recompute the colors of each point:
To extend our animations to have our points pop into place in addition to the color tween, we can animate the radius by specifying
This time we used the expanded transitions definition which allows us to set an
for the animation to follow. The effect is shown below:

That was pretty easy! Thanks deck.gl, you're the best. But often times things look even cooler if we can add a little delay to each point instead of having them all animate in at once. To solve that, we have to do something a bit more complex and use a custom layer.
Add in point delay with a custom layer
I've created a layer I call the
that allows you to render in points with delay specified by a function, similar to how
work. I won't cover the details of how it works here, but please feel free to view
and tune it to your needs.
works by specifying three new properties on your layer:
How far through the animation you currently are (a value between 0 and 1). At 0, the animation has not started. At 1, all points are done animating.

How long a single point takes to animate as a proportion of the animation progress (a value between 0 and 1). A value of 0.25 means any given point will take 25% of the animation duration to completely animate (works best with linear easing on
). The final point begins animating when

A function mapping from a data point to a value between 0 and 1 representing when this point should begin animating. A value of 0 means it will begin animating immediately and 1 means it will be the last point to animate.
Let's look at our library example:
// value between 0 and 1 representing animation progress
// create a scale that maps longitudinal values to values between 0 and 1
// based on the min and max longitudes in the dataset.
// specify how far we are through the animation (value between 0 and 1)
// specify how long a point takes to completely animate as a
// proportion of the overall animation progress (value between 0 and 1)
// specify the delay factor for each point (value between 0 and 1)
to new values between 0 and 1 and tell deck.gl to update its layers, we will see our points animate in. A simple way to get
to animate with regular updates is to use
// update this property to have value 1
// each tick, update the deck.gl layers with new values
// see full source code for details
There's plenty of other modifications you can do with the

and I tend to just edit the shader for whatever I am currently looking to do on an ad-hoc basis. I encourage you to do the same! Or even better, make it more robust and release it as a reusable component for everyone to enjoy :)
Bonus: make things look fancy with additive blending

Now to really make our points pop, we can dip into the wonderful world of blending. Additive blending is when overlapping colors have their RGB values added together to determine the color that is shown on screen. This typically results in brighter regions and can sometimes feel like a nice glow effect (although typically glows use blurring in addition to this).
Luckily, it doesn't take much to turn on additive blending in deck.gl, we simply provide some parameters to our layer:
// turn on additive blending to make them look more glowy
After you get your fix animating points, maybe you'll move on to animating the ArcLayer.
There's a great starting point here
. I ended up using something similar to produce the following video:
Thanks for reading! If you've got any questions or comments, reach out to me on Twitter

frontmatter.title: Animating points on maps with deck.gl
frontmatter.description: Learn how to animate points on maps using Uber's deck.gl library with the built-in transition support and custom shaders.
